learning_outcomes.description: Apply foundational knowledge in drug physiochemical properties to drug design and medicines use
Apply physiochemical principles to the formulation of liquid dosage forms and medicines use
Collate, analyse, and interpret pharmaceutical science data to inform decisions
Perform pharmaceutical calculations relating to liquid medicines
Design and prepare accurate and pharmaceutically elegant extemporaneous liquid dosage forms

assessments.due_date:
Quiz 1 (10%): Drug Design and Analysis Online Quiz 27/03/2026 5:00 pm

Quiz 2 (10%): Liquid Dosage Form Design Online Quiz 1/05/2026 5:00 pm

Quiz 3 (5%): Pharmaceutical Calculations Online Quiz 15/05/2026 5:00 pm
assessments.task_description:
There are three online quizzes held during semester, named the 'Drug Design & Analysis Online Quiz', 'Liquid Dosage Form Design Online Quiz', and the 'Pharmaceutical Calculations Online Quiz'.


Quiz 1: Drug Design and Analysis Online Quiz (10% weighting):

  • ONE attempt is permitted between 19/03/2026 5:00 pm and 27/03/2026 5:00 pm.
  • The quiz questions will cover Module 1 content (i.e. Drug Design to Optimise PK/PD; Drug Analysis including the Drug Analysis Practical; and Design of Biological Drugs).


Quiz 2: Liquid Dosage Form Design Online Quiz (10% weighting):

  • ONE attempt is permitted between 23/04/2026 5:00 pm and 1/05/2026 5:00 pm.
  • The quiz questions will cover Module 2 content (i.e. Solutions; Buffers, Cosolvents, and Complexation; Dispersions including the Dispersions Practical; and Drug Stability).


Quiz 3: Pharmaceutical Calculations Online Quiz (5% weighting):

  • THREE attempts are permitted between 1/05/2026 5:00 pm and 15/05/2026 5:00 pm, with the best mark counting towards the course grade.
  • The quiz involves various pharmaceutical calculations, mostly related to compounding and dispensing liquid dosage forms.


Additional information about the quizzes:

  • These online quizzes are Blackboard tests that are located in the Assessment folder of the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site.
  • The duration of each quiz is 80 minutes. An additional 10 mins is provided as a buffer for any issues that might arise during your quiz. The quiz timer is set to 90 minutes, after which your answers will be saved and submitted automatically (unless you submit them sooner manually). The timer will continue to run if you exit the quiz.
  • The format may be a mixture of question types, for example: calculation, multiple choice, multiple answer, matching, ordering, fill in the blank/s, jumbled sentence/s, either/or (e.g. true/false), short answer, and short essay style questions.
  • Questions may be provided randomly from a pool; therefore, each student may receive a different but equivalent quiz.
  • The quiz will be marked electronically. Correct answers will be awarded the marks indicated beside the question; incorrect answers will be awarded zero.
  • This is an individual assessment that you are required to undertake without any form of communication with other students.
  • As an online quiz undertaken in the venue of your choice, the quiz is open-book.
  • This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of this assessment task will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI will provide only limited support and guidance.
  • See Learn.UQ (Blackboard) and UQ Extend for more details and marking criteria.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission: These online quizzes will be completed and submitted electronically in the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site from the venue of your choice.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
20/05/2026 3:00 pm

Held in the scheduled workshop at UQ Dutton Park in Week 12.
assessments.task_description:
General information:

  • This invigilated quiz will be completed in person at UQ Dutton Park during the scheduled workshop in Week 12. 
  • The quiz is paper-based with ONE attempt permitted.
  • The quiz involves various pharmaceutical calculations, mostly related to compounding and dispensing liquid dosage forms, which you will practise in a series of practicals conducted regularly during the semester.
  • The quiz duration is 40 minutes.
  • Questions may be provided from a pool; therefore, each student may receive a different but equivalent quiz.
  • The marks allocated to each question are provided on the paper; answers may be awarded zero, part-marks, or full marks as applicable to each question.
  • This is an individual assessment that will be held under exam conditions.
  • See Learn.UQ (Blackboard) and UQ Extend for more details, a sample/practice quiz, and marking criteria.

Items that may be brought into the quiz:

  • Your Student ID.
  • Calculators must be Casio FX82 series or UQ approved (labelled).
  • Pens: all answers must be written in indelible pen, not pencil and not erasable pen. Mistakes must be neatly crossed through; do not use whiteout.

Items that may NOT be brought into the quiz:

  • Any other items, including any electronic devices.

Materials that will be supplied:

  • The question sheets (including space to provide answers).
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission: The Pharmaceutical Calculations In-person Quiz will be completed and submitted during the scheduled workshop at UQ Dutton Park in Week 12. The Deferred Pharmaceutical Calculations In-Person Quiz will be held at UQ Dutton Park on the Friday of Week 13 at a time specified by the School; refer to the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site for the starting time.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.due_date:
28/05/2026

Held in the scheduled practical at UQ Dutton Park in Week 13. Refer to the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site for the starting time.
assessments.task_description:
This invigilated practical exam will be completed in person in the laboratories at UQ Dutton Park during the scheduled practical in Week 13. Refer to the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site for the starting times.

Items that may be brought into the examination:

  • Your Student ID.
  • Laboratory coat, closed-in shoes and safety glasses are mandatory.
  • Calculators must be Casio FX82 series or UQ approved (labelled).
  • Australian Pharmaceutical Formulary (APF) - page tags are allowed, but annotations are not permitted.
  • Pens: all answers must be written in indelible pen, not pencil and not erasable pen. Mistakes must be neatly crossed through; do not use whiteout.

Items that may NOT be brought into the examination:

  • Any other items, including any electronic devices.

Materials that will be supplied:

  • All ingredients and equipment required for the product that you will prepare and dispense, the prescription details, a compounding worksheet, and one copy of the current edition of the APF per laboratory.

Instructions:

You will have 90 minutes to complete the exam.

You will work independently to prepare and dispense one assigned prescription. You will complete appropriate calculations, prepare the product, fill out a compounding worksheet, and label the product.

  • Complete the compounding worksheet as you go. Ingredient weights and volumes entered into the compounding worksheet must match the value on the balance or in the measuring cylinder and must be checked by an invigilator. Raise your hand when you need an invigilator to check and sign against your entries.
  • Prepare a suitable label and apply it to the product.
  • To pass, your product must be of acceptable quality to be supplied to a patient. When you consider your product is ready to be supplied, submit the labelled product and compounding worksheet for assessment.
  • Three components are marked: the product, the label, and the compounding worksheet. A passing grade is achieved when all three components are of acceptable quality for the medication to be dispensed to a patient.


See Learn.UQ (Blackboard) and UQ Extend for more details, sample/practice exams, and marking criteria.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission: The Compounding Skills Assessment will be completed and submitted during the scheduled practical class at UQ Dutton Park in Week 13. The Deferred Compounding Skills Assessment will be held at UQ Dutton Park in the week following the exam period. Refer to the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site for the starting times.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: Drugs and Liquid Dosage Forms Exam
assessments.task_description:
General information:

  • This invigilated in-person digital exam will be completed on your own device (laptop) using the Inspera platform during the end of semester exam period.
  • Further details about Inspera, including an introduction to Inspera functionality and how to prepare for your digital exam, are available here: Assessments in Inspera.
  • The exam questions will cover Module 1 and Module 2 content (i.e. Drug Design to Optimise PK/PD; Drug Analysis, including the Drug Analysis Practical; Design of Biological Drugs; Solutions; Buffers, Cosolvents, and Complexation; Dispersions, including the Dispersions Practical; and Drug Stability).
  • See Learn.UQ (Blackboard) and UQ Extend for more details, a sample/practice exam, and marking criteria.

Items that may be brought into the examination:

  • Your Student ID.
  • Calculators must be Casio FX82 series or UQ approved (labelled).
  • Digital exam equipment (Laptop and nominated device for multi-factor authentication only).
  • Pens for rough working.

Items that may NOT be brought into the examination:

  • Any other items.

Materials that will be supplied:

  • The PHRM2201 Pharmaceutical Sciences 2A: Drugs and Liquid Dosage Forms Formula Sheet.
  • Rough paper.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission: Your responses to the questions will be submitted during the exam using your own device (laptop).
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Active online learning via UQ Extend

The content for this course is delivered via UQ Extend. Each week you should work through the active online learning on UQ Extend. You will get the most out of the weekly workshops if you have viewed the content on UQ Extend before attending the workshop.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Active online learning via UQ Extend The content for this course is delivered via UQ Extend. Each week you should work through the active online learning on UQ Extend. You will get the most out of the weekly workshops if you have viewed the content on UQ Extend before attending the workshop.

learning_activities.topic:
Course overview workshop

This workshop will give an overview of the course.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Course overview workshop This workshop will give an overview of the course.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 4(02 Mar - 22 Mar)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 1 - Drug Design and Analysis Workshops

Drug design & analysis. Workshops will cover: W2 & W3) Drug Design; W4) Drug Analysis; W4) Integrated Drug Design and Analysis.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 1 - Drug Design and Analysis Workshops Drug design & analysis. Workshops will cover: W2 & W3) Drug Design; W4) Drug Analysis; W4) Integrated Drug Design and Analysis.

learning_activities.topic:
Module 1 - Drug Analysis Practical

Three-hour practical in the laboratories at UQ Dutton Park. Working in a team, you will test paracetamol tablets to estimate their content of paracetamol using the Assay of Content test from the British Pharmacopoeia (BP).


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 1 - Drug Analysis Practical Three-hour practical in the laboratories at UQ Dutton Park.  Working in a team, you will test paracetamol tablets to estimate their content of paracetamol using the Assay of Content test from the British Pharmacopoeia (BP).

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 6 To Week 8(30 Mar - 26 Apr)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 2 - Liquid Dosage Form Design Workshops

Liquid dosage form design. Workshops will cover: W6) Solutions; W7) Buffers, Cosolvents, and Complexation; W8) Dispersions; W8) Integrated Liquid Dosage Form Design.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 2 - Liquid Dosage Form Design Workshops Liquid dosage form design. Workshops will cover: W6) Solutions; W7) Buffers, Cosolvents, and Complexation; W8) Dispersions; W8) Integrated Liquid Dosage Form Design.

learning_activities.topic:
Module 2 - Dispersions Practical

Three-hour practical in the laboratories at UQ Dutton Park campus. Working in a team, you will consider how important is it to shake the bottle of a dispersion formulation. Specifically, you will prepare aspirin suspension then investigate the variation in dose that a patient would receive when taking your product. You will evaluate your aspirin suspension using the British Pharmacopoeia (BP) test for content uniformity of liquid dosage forms.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 2 - Dispersions Practical Three-hour practical in the laboratories at UQ Dutton Park campus. Working in a team, you will consider how important is it to shake the bottle of a dispersion formulation. Specifically, you will prepare aspirin suspension then investigate the variation in dose that a patient would receive when taking your product. You will evaluate your aspirin suspension using the British Pharmacopoeia (BP) test for content uniformity of liquid dosage forms.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 9 To Week 13(27 Apr - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 3 - Compounding Liquid Dosage Forms Workshops

Compounding Liquid Dosage Forms. Workshops will cover: W9) Pharmaceutical Calculations and Compounding Solutions; W10) Compounding Topical and Mucosal Liquids; W11) Compounding Suspensions and Emulsions; W12) Compounding Skills Assessment (incorporating the Pharmaceutical Calculations In-person Quiz); W13) Integrated Compounding.


Learning outcomes: L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 3 - Compounding Liquid Dosage Forms Workshops Compounding Liquid Dosage Forms. Workshops will cover: W9) Pharmaceutical Calculations and Compounding Solutions; W10) Compounding Topical and Mucosal Liquids; W11) Compounding Suspensions and Emulsions; W12) Compounding Skills Assessment (incorporating the Pharmaceutical Calculations In-person Quiz); W13) Integrated Compounding.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 9 To Week 13(27 Apr - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 3 - Compounding Liquid Dosage Forms Practicals

Three-hour practicals in the laboratories at UQ Dutton Park. Working individually, you will practice extemporaneous compounding by compounding and dispensing various liquid dosage forms: W9) Compounding Solutions; W10) Compounding Topical and Mucosal Liquids; W11) Compounding Suspensions and Emulsions; W12) Mock Compounding Skills Assessment (practice exam); W13) Compounding Skills Assessment (exam).


Learning outcomes: L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 3 - Compounding Liquid Dosage Forms Practicals Three-hour practicals in the laboratories at UQ Dutton Park. Working individually, you will practice extemporaneous compounding by compounding and dispensing various liquid dosage forms: W9) Compounding Solutions; W10) Compounding Topical and Mucosal Liquids; W11) Compounding Suspensions and Emulsions; W12) Mock Compounding Skills Assessment (practice exam); W13) Compounding Skills Assessment (exam).
